contribute/contribute-to-gns3.title: Contribute to GNS3
contribute/contribute-to-gns3.description: The GNS3 community welcomes new contributors. Don’t be afraid to make mistakes - we are here to help.

emulators/adding-vmware-vms-to-gns3-topo.title: Adding VMware VMs to GNS3 Topologies

emulators/cisco-ios-images-for-dynamips.title: Cisco IOS images for Dynamips
emulators/cisco-ios-images-for-dynamips.description: GNS3 offers multiple ways to emulate IOS. For older images, we use and maintain Dynamips; an emulator dedicated to emulate some Cisco hardware. Dynamips can run unmodified IOS images. In the new GNS3 1.4, there is a way to run a second category of switches and routers. These are classified as Routing and Switching virtual machines (or R+Svms) for short. What are the differences? Here are the major differences:

emulators/create-a-docker-container-for-.title: Create a docker container for GNS3
emulators/create-a-docker-container-for-.description: This tutorial is for users who never used Docker, and would like to create a Docker container for GNS3.

emulators/docker-support-in-gns3.title: Docker support in GNS3
emulators/docker-support-in-gns3.description: Docker container support was added as a feature starting with GNS3 1.5. Work on this feature was started by Goran Cetusic during the Google Summer Of Code and finished by the GNS3 core team.

emulators/non-native-iou-for-windows-and.title: Non-Native IOU for Windows and OSX
emulators/non-native-iou-for-windows-and.description: IOU is IOS on Unix (Solaris, if you want to be specific). It's a version of IOS compiled to run on workstations. It's faster and lighter than emulation. Cisco transitioned to IOL images, which are x86-64 compatible versions of IOS that natively run in Linux. Since everyone and their kid brother still refers to IOL images as “IOU”, that convention is used for the remainder of this document.

emulators/qemu-system-uuid.title: Qemu system UUID
emulators/qemu-system-uuid.description: Like any real computer, Qemu attributes a UUID to the system. This is stored in the SMBIOS:

emulators/vpcs.title: VPCS
emulators/vpcs.description: Virtual PC Simulator is a program written by Paul Meng, which allows you to simulate a lightweight PC supporting DHCP and ping. It consumes only 2MB of RAM per instance,  and does not require an additional image.

emulators/which-emulators-should-i-use.title: Which emulator should I use?
emulators/which-emulators-should-i-use.description: GNS3 supports multiple emulators which you can use in your GNS3 projects. This gives you lots of flexibility when building topologies.

getting-started/installation/download-32.title: Download GNS3 for Windows 32 bit
getting-started/installation/download-32.description: If you use a 32 bit version of Windows, you will need to use GNS3 1.3.13 (or older). 32 bit support was dropped starting with GNS3 1.4.

getting-started/installation/download-gn.title: Downloading the GNS3 VM
getting-started/installation/download-gn.description: Which Virtualization Software? VirtualBox or VMware?

getting-started/installation/esxi.title: Install the GNS3 VM on ESXi
getting-started/installation/esxi.description: VMware ESXi and VMware workstation are two totally different products. If you want instructions for VMware Workstation or VMware Fusion read this document.

getting-started/installation/one-server-.title: One GNS3 server, multiple clients
getting-started/installation/one-server-.description: This documentation is only for GNS3 2.0 and later

getting-started/installation/remote-serv.title: Install GNS3 on a remote server
getting-started/installation/remote-serv.description: If you need more resources for bigger topologies, you can install GNS3 on a remote server. This could be on:

getting-started/setup-wizard-gns3-vm.title: GNS3 Setup wizard with the GNS3 VM
getting-started/setup-wizard-gns3-vm.description: Which Virtualization Software? VirtualBox or VMware?

how-to-guides/configure-gns3-to-use-an-a.title: Configure GNS3 to use an additional remote server
how-to-guides/configure-gns3-to-use-an-a.description: Configure GNS3 to use an additional remote server

how-to-guides/how-to-use-console-applica.title: How to use applications with the GNS3 Web interface
how-to-guides/how-to-use-console-applica.description: A web client pack must be installed on your operating system in order to launch local applications needed to work with the GNS3 Web interface. We currently support Telnet, VNC, SPICE and packet capture applications.

how-to-guides/importing-vmx-and-vqfx-int.title: Importing vMX and vQFX into GNS3
how-to-guides/importing-vmx-and-vqfx-int.description: Important edit - see bottom of the document!

troubleshooting-faq/where-do-i-get-ios-i.title: Where do I get IOS images?

using-gns3/administration/client-server-.title: Client server SSL encryption
using-gns3/administration/client-server-.description: GNS3 supports secured network communications between the GNS3 GUI and GNS3 server using SSL. SSL mode is not supported for the GNS3 server on Windows but you can use it for clients. You will need a SSL certificate, if you don't have one, it is possible to generate a self signed certificate using this script (OpenSSL must be installed):

using-gns3/administration/gns3-security.title: GNS3 Security
using-gns3/administration/gns3-security.description: Users of GNS3 need to bear in mind that it is a tool designed to be used for experimentation/learning, not for managing Virtual Machines or appliances in a production environment.

using-gns3/administration/gns3-server-co.title: GNS3 server configuration file
using-gns3/administration/gns3-server-co.description: If you want to run the GNS3 server without the GUI, you can configure it with via an ini file.

using-gns3/administration/running-gns3-s.title: Running the GNS3 server as a daemon
using-gns3/administration/running-gns3-s.description: You will find a sample init script for various systems inside the init directory of the gns3-server project//github.com/GNS3/gns3-server/tree/master/init

using-gns3/administration/scale-gns3.title: Scale GNS3
using-gns3/administration/scale-gns3.description: GNS3 itself doesn’t have limitation on the number of nodes you can run into it. The limitation will be your hardware.

using-gns3/advanced/configuration-transf.title: Configuration transfer to QEMU VMs
using-gns3/advanced/configuration-transf.description: GNS3 v2.2.18 introduces a feature to transfer files,

using-gns3/advanced/connect-gns3-interne.title: Connect GNS3 to the Internet (local server)

using-gns3/advanced/create-a-new-version.title: Create a new version of an appliance
using-gns3/advanced/create-a-new-version.description: Manufacturers release new versions of their appliances every day. The GNS3 community does not always know about these new releases and updates to the appliance file, but GNS3 allows you to use an unknown version of an appliance.

using-gns3/advanced/hubs-and-switches.title: GNS3's built-in Hub and Switch devices

using-gns3/advanced/move-from-iouvm-gns3.title: Move from IOUVM to GNS3 VM
using-gns3/advanced/move-from-iouvm-gns3.description: Starting with GNS3 v1.4,  the IOUVM was deprecated in favor of the GNS3 VM.

using-gns3/advanced/port-name-formatting.title: Port name formatting
using-gns3/advanced/port-name-formatting.description: Some nodes (like QEMU VMs) will allow you to personalize the name of its ports, in order to match the name of the interfaces inside the emulator.

using-gns3/advanced/settings-profiles.title: Settings profiles
using-gns3/advanced/settings-profiles.description: This documentation is only for GNS3 2.0 and later

using-gns3/advanced/special-ip-addresses.title: Special IP addresses in GNS3
using-gns3/advanced/special-ip-addresses.description: GNS3 uses several RFC1918 private IP ranges by default. If possible we recommend to avoid using them in your topology in order to limit conflicts.

using-gns3/advanced/the-nat-node.title: The NAT node
using-gns3/advanced/the-nat-node.description: Starting with GNS3 2.0,  the NAT node became available. This node allows you to connect a topology to internet via NAT. The Internet node was deprecated in favor of this node, and the Cloud node.

using-gns3/beginners/change-node-symbol.title: Use custom symbols in GNS3
using-gns3/beginners/change-node-symbol.description: Beginning with GNS3 1.4 you have been able to change the symbol for a node (or supply your own).  Starting with GNS3 2.2.0, additional style types of symbols for the various device types are included by default. You can still add your own custom symbols if you wish (that hasn’t changed).

using-gns3/beginners/import-gns3-applian.title: Import GNS3 appliance
using-gns3/beginners/import-gns3-applian.description: This document assumes that you already have both the GNS3 Graphical User Interface installed (GNS3-all-in-one) and the GNS3 VM integrated with GNS3. Please refer to other guides for more details on how to install the GNS3 all-in-one package and how to download and configure the GNS3 VM.

using-gns3/beginners/install-from-market.title: Install an appliance from the GNS3 Marketplace

using-gns3/beginners/link-control.title: Link Control
using-gns3/beginners/link-control.description: available in GNS3 version 2.1 and later.

using-gns3/beginners/the-console-termina.title: The console terminal
using-gns3/beginners/the-console-termina.description: GNS3 uses Solar-PuTTY as the default console terminal in Windows* (see note), and will attempt to use the default system terminal in other operating systems (gnome-terminal, for example, in vanilla Ubuntu).

using-gns3/design/architecture.title: Architecture
using-gns3/design/architecture.description: GNS3 can be divided in four parts:

using-gns3/design/why-gns3-uses-uuid.title: Why does GNS3 use UUIDs?
using-gns3/design/why-gns3-uses-uuid.description: A commonly asked  question about GNS3, is why I can’t easily find the files of a node or project names on disk. It’s due to the usage of UUIDs in folder naming.
